{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name =King's Artillery Regiment |native_name =Kongens Artilleriregiment |image =Coat of arms for King's Artillery Regiment.svg |caption = |dates =1982 ‚Äì 2005 |country ={{flagicon|Denmark}}[[Denmark]] |allegiance = |branch =[[File:Flag of Denmark (state).svg|25px]] [[Royal Danish Army]] |type = |role = |size = |command_structure= |garrison =Sj√¶lsmark kaserne |garrison_label = |nickname =KAR |patron = |motto =''Frisk og Frejdigt Fremad'' (Fresh and Boldly Forward) |colors =[[File:King's Artillery Regiment Stable belt.png|80px]] |colors_label =Regimental belt |march = |mascot = |equipment = |equipment_label = |battles = |anniversaries = |decorations = |battle_honours = |disbanded =2005 <!-- Commanders --> |commander1 = |commander1_label = |notable_commanders= <!-- Insignia --> |identification_symbol = |identification_symbol_label= }} The '''King's Artillery Regiment''' ({{lang-da|Kongens Artilleriregiment, KAR}}) was an [[artillery]] regiment of the [[Royal Danish Army]].
==History== The ''Kongens Artilleriregiment'' was formed on 1 August 1982 by merging [[Kronens Artilleriregiment]] from Sj√¶lsmark barracks and [[Sj√¶llandske Artilleriregiment]] from [[Holb√¶k barracks]]. On 1 November 2005 ''Kongens Artilleriregiment'' was merged with [[Dronningens Artilleriregiment]] to create the new artillery regiment, [[Danske Artilleriregiment]]. The regiment was located on [[Sj√¶lsmark barracks]].
==Units==
* 1st Artillery Battalion (1982-2004) * 2nd Artillery Battalion (1982-2004) * 5th Artillery Battalion (1982-2004) * 13th Anti Air Artillery Battalion (1982-2000) * 14th Light Artillery Battalion (1982-1996) * 16th Light Artillery Battalion (1982-1990) Transferred to [[North Jutland Artillery Regiment]] * 17th Heavy Artillery Battery (1982-1996) - 17th MLRS Battery (1997-2004) * 21st Light Artillery Battalion (1982-2000) * 22nd Light Artillery Battalion (1982-2000) * 32nd Heavy Artillery Battalion (1982-1985) - 32nd Artillery Battalion (1985-2004)
{{Regiments of Denmark}}

{{Infobox anthem |image = Goat_(CoA_of_Istria).svg |title = Krasna zemljo |english_title = Beautiful Country |prefix = Regional |country = [[Istria County|Istria]] {{CRO}} |composer = [[Matko Braj≈°a Ra≈°an]] |author = [[Ivan Cukon]] |adopted = 2002 }}
Lyrics of the song "'''Krasna zemljo'''" (''"Beautiful land"'') were written by [[Ivan Cukon]] in 1912, and the music was composed by [[Matko Braj≈°a Ra≈°an]]. The song was written as the ''[[Hymn]] of the Company [[Saints Cyril and Methodius]]'' and later became an unofficial anthem of the region of [[Istria]].
As the song was widely accepted as the anthem of the region, the assembly of the [[Istria County]] proclaimed the song as the regional anthem of Istria on 23 September 2002. Despite Istria has officially adopted [[Croatian language|Croatian]]-[[Italian language|Italian]] [[bilingualism]], the anthem is only sung in Croatian.
== Official lyrics ==
=== Krasna zemljo ===
<poem> Krasna zemljo, Istro mila dome roda hrvatskog Kud se ori pjesan vila, s [[Uƒçka|Uƒçke]] tja do mora tvog.
Glas se ƒçuje oko Ra≈°e, ƒçuje [[Mirna (Croatia)|Mirna]], Draga, Lim Sve se di≈æe ≈°to je na≈°e za rod gori srcem svim.
Slava tebi [[Pazin]] - grade koj' nam ƒçuva≈° rodni kraj Divne li ste, oj Livade nek' vas mine tuƒëi sjaj!
Sva se Istra ≈°irom budi [[Pula]], [[Buzet]], [[Lo≈°inj]], [[Cres]] Svud poma≈æu dobri ljudi nauk ≈æari kano krijes. </poem>
== English Translation ==
<poem> Beautiful land, dear Istria home of the Croatian kin Where the song of fairies sounds from [[Uƒçka]] to your sea.
The voice is heard throughout the [[Ra≈°a (river)|Ra≈°a]], heard by [[Mirna (Croatia)|Mirna]], [[Mo≈°ƒáeniƒçka Draga|Draga]], [[Lim (Croatia)|Lim]] Everything is rising that is ours, its heart burning for its kin
Glory to you [[Pazin]] - city you that guard our birthplace You're beautiful, oh [[Livade, Croatia|Livade]] let others shine cease upon you
all of Istria is waking up, [[Pula]], [[Buzet]], [[Lo≈°inj]], [[Cres]] everywhere the good people are helping, knowledge is glowing like embers </poem>
== External links and references == {{Portal|Croatia}} * [http://www.istra-istria.hr/index.php?id=605 Istria County] - the official page about the anthem
{{Nationalanthemsofeurope}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Krasna Zemljo}} [[Category:Regional songs]] [[Category:Croatian songs]] [[Category:Istria]] [[Category:European anthems]]

revision.text:
The '''Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918''' ('''MBTA'''), [[Codification (law)|codified]] at {{UnitedStatesCode|16|703|712}} (although ¬ß709 is omitted), is a [[United States federal law]], first enacted in 1916 to implement [[Migratory Bird Treaty|the convention for the protection of migratory birds]] between the [[United States]] and [[Great Britain]] (acting on behalf of [[Canada]]).<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fws.gov/migratorybirds/RegulationsPolicies/mbta/43603%20QA%201013%20rule.pdf | title = Migratory Bird Management Information: List of Protected Birds (10.13) Questions and Answers | publisher = US Fish & Wildlife Service | accessdate = 7 August 2015 | format = PDF}}</ref> The statute makes it unlawful without a waiver to pursue, hunt, take, capture, kill, or sell birds listed therein as [[bird migration|migratory birds]]. The statute does not discriminate between live or dead birds and also grants full protection to any bird parts including feathers, eggs, and nests. Over 800 species are currently on the list.<ref>[http://www.fws.gov/birds/policies-and-regulations/laws-legislations/migratory-bird-treaty-act.php "Migratory Bird Treaty Act Birds Protected"], [[U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service]]. Accessed January 11, 2016.</ref>
Some exceptions to the act, including the [[eagle feather law]], are enacted in federal regulations ({{CodeFedReg|50|22}}), which regulate the taking, possession, and transportation of [[bald eagle]]s, [[golden eagle]]s, and their "parts, nests, and eggs" for "scientific, educational, and depredation control purposes; for the religious purposes of [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indian]] tribes; and to protect other interests in a particular locality." Enrolled members of [[federally recognized tribe]]s may apply for an eagle permit for use in "[[bona fide]] tribal religious ceremonies."<ref>[http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr;sid=a364a1e33a25659e93d90c9cfafdbcfd;rgn=div5;view=text;node=50%3A6.0.1.1.5;idno=50;cc=ecfr#50:6.0.1.1.5.3.1.2]{{dead link|date=September 2018}}</ref>
The [[U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service]] issues permits for otherwise prohibited activities under the act. These include permits for taxidermy, falconry, propagation, scientific and educational use, and depredation, an example of the latter being the killing of geese near an airport, where they pose a danger to aircraft.
The Act was enacted in an era when many bird species were threatened by the commercial trade in birds and bird [[feather]]s. The Act was one of the first federal environmental laws (the [[Lacey Act]] had been enacted in 1900). The Act replaced the earlier [[Weeks-McLean Act]] (1913). Since 1918, similar conventions between the United States and four other nations have been made and incorporated into the MBTA: [[Mexico]] (1936), [[Japan]] (1972) and the [[Soviet Union]] (1976, now its [[successor state]] [[Russia]]). Some of the conventions stipulate protections not only for the birds themselves, but also for habitats and environs necessary for the birds' survival.
Constitutionally this law is of interest as it is a use of the federal treaty-making power to override the provisions of state law. The principle that the federal government may do this was upheld in the case ''[[Missouri v. Holland]]''.
== Sections == *¬ß 703: Taking, killing, or possessing migratory birds unlawfully *¬ß 704: Determination as to when and how migratory birds may be taken, killed, or possessed *¬ß 705: Transportation or importation of migratory birds; when unlawful *¬ß 706: [[Arrest]]s; [[search warrant]]s *¬ß 707: Violations and penalties; [[Forfeiture (law)|forfeitures]] *¬ß 708: State or Territorial laws or regulations *¬ß 709: Omitted *¬ß709a: Authorization of appropriations *¬ß 710: Partial invalidity; short title *¬ß 711: Breeding and sale for food supply *¬ß 712: Treaty and convention implementing regulations; seasonal taking of migratory birds for essential needs of [[Alaska Natives|indigenous Alaskans]] to preserve and maintain stocks of the birds; protection and conservation of the birds
== History == {{see also|Timeline of environmental events}}
[[Louis Marshall]] had a key influence as an [[Intervention (law)|intervenor]] on a landmark case before the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] underscoring the right and responsibility of the federal government for environmental protection and conservation. In a friend of the court brief in ''[[Missouri v. Holland]]'' on behalf of the Association for the Protection of the Adirondacks, Marshall successfully persuaded the court to uphold the Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918, between the United States and Canada.<ref>^ Reznikoff, Charles, ed. 1957. Louis Marshall: Champion of Liberty. Selected Papers and Addresses. 2 vols. p. 1177 Philadelphia: The Jewish Publication Society of America, frontispiece</ref> As characterized by Adler, Marshall argued, "the United States did have the power to create such legislation; that Congress was well within its rights; and that the Act was constitutional"; and, further, "If Congress possessed plenary powers to legislate for the protection of the public domain, then it had to take into account all possibility for such protection", including protection of migratory birds, "these natural guardians" against "hostile insects, which, if not held in check ... would result in the inevitable destruction" of "both prairie and forest lands". According to Handlin, Marshall's intervention "was a major factor in the decision."<ref>Reznikoff, Charles, ed. 1957. Louis Marshall: Champion of Liberty. Selected Papers and Addresses. 2 vols. p. xviii Philadelphia: The Jewish Publication Society of America, frontispiece</ref>
=== Recent revisions === In the 24 August 2006 edition of the [[Federal Register]], the U.S. [[Department of the Interior]]'s [[Fish and Wildlife Service]] proposed adding 152 species, removing 12 species, and correcting/updating the common or scientific names of numerous others. Reasons for the proposed revisions include birds mistakenly omitted previously, new evidence on geographic distribution, taxonomic changes, etc. In addition, the mute swan (''[[Cygnus olor]]''), which was afforded temporary protection due to court order since 2001, is formally excluded from protection in the proposal due to "nonnative and human introduced" status. The previous update to the list occurred on 5 April 1985.
On January 9, 2001, the US Supreme Court, in a split vote of 5 to 4, (''Solid Waste Agency, of [[Skokie, Illinois]] vs [[US Army Corps of Engineers]]'') threw out what has been dubbed the [[migratory bird rule]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/99-1178.ZS.html |title=Solid Waste Agency Of Northern Cook Cty. V.Army Corps Of Engineers |publisher=Law.cornell.edu |date= |accessdate=2018-09-21}}</ref> A case that pitted a consortium of towns around Chicago over isolated wetlands, inhabited or visited by over 100 migratory bird species, against the US Army Corps of Engineers. In this case, Skokie, Illinois, wanted abandoned quarries filled with water, but not connected to another or navigable body of water to serve as a site for a solid waste facility. For the previous 15 years, lower courts had sustained the law in favor of migratory birds, siding with the Army Corps.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/01/us/01water.html?hp | work=The New York Times | title=Rulings Restrict Clean Water Act, Foiling E.P.A | first1=Charles | last1=Duhigg | first2=Janet | last2=Roberts | date=2010-02-28 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref>
At least one state reacted to the new Supreme Court ruling by restoring isolated wetlands protection: 2001 Wisconsin Act 6, is the first of its kind nationwide to restore wetlands regulation to the state after federal authority had been revoked. It restores protection to over one million acres (4,000 km¬≤) of isolated wetlands in Wisconsin. On May 7, 2001, Wisconsin Governor [[Scott McCallum]] signed a bill protecting wetlands by placing Wisconsin wetlands regulation under the jurisdiction of the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources. Bipartisan state legislators fully supported the bill and felt it was necessary after the Supreme Court ruled that the federal clean water act didn't give the corps authority over decisions involving isolated wetlands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsn.org/wetlands/wetlandsbattle.html|title=How We Won The Battle For Isolated Wetlands in Wisconsin|first=Will|last=Fantle|date=|website=www.wsn.org}}</ref>
== Impact on private property owners == [[Migratory birds]] may seek respite within trees or on buildings considered [[Property law|private property]]. The '''Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918''' prohibits the removal of all listed species or their parts (feathers, eggs, nests, etc.) from such property. However, in extreme circumstances, a federal permit might be obtained for the relocation of listed species (in some states a state permit is required ''in addition'' to a federal permit). Pursuant to the spirit of the treaty, it is not trivial to obtain a permit; the applicant must meet a certain criteria as outlined in Title 50, [[Code of Federal Regulations]], 21.27, Special Purpose Permits.<ref>{{CodeFedReg|50|21|27}}</ref>
The permit applicant is generally a contractor who specializes in wildlife relocation. When hiring a contractor to trap and relocate any animal from one's property, the private property owner is well advised to attain proof of such permits before any trapping activity begins, as trapping without the necessary paperwork is common in the United States.
Most wildlife management professionals consider relocation actions undue harm to the birds, particularly since relocated birds (being migratory) often return to the same property the next year. In the case of trapping and relocation, ''harm'' is brought on by or can result in: * ''Breaking'', a term describing increased susceptibility to disease brought on by the stress of capture and relocation * Difficulty in establishing territory at the new location * Separation of family members and the stunting of juveniles' natural progression into adulthood
== Game birds and hunted species == The migratory bird conventions with Canada and Mexico define "game birds" as those species belonging to the following families:
*[[Anatidae]] (swans, geese, and ducks) *[[Rallidae]] (rails, gallinules, and coots) *[[Gruidae]] (cranes) *[[Charadriidae]] (plovers and lapwings) *[[Haematopodidae]] (oystercatchers) *[[Recurvirostridae]] (stilts and avocets) *[[Scolopacidae]] (sandpipers, phalaropes, and allies) *[[Columbidae]] (pigeons and doves).
The Migratory Bird Treaty Act, which implements the conventions, grants the Secretary of the Interior the authority to establish hunting seasons for any of the migratory game bird species listed above. In actuality, the Fish and Wildlife Service has determined that hunting is appropriate only for those species for which there is a long tradition of hunting, and for which hunting is consistent with their population status and their long-term conservation. It is inconceivable, for example, that we will ever see legalized hunting of plovers, curlews, or the many other species of shorebirds whose populations were devastated by market gunners in the last decades of the 19th century.
Although the Migratory Bird Treaty Act considers some 170 species to be "game birds," less than 60 species are typically hunted each year. The Fish and Wildlife Service publishes migratory game bird regulations in the Federal Register. Those species for which hunting regulations have been established at some point during the past 10 years are designated with an asterisk (*) in the following list.{{clarify|date=April 2018|reason=what list?}} However, such a designation does not necessarily indicate that a given species can be taken legally in your State or locality. For regulations specific to your locality, you should consult with your State's natural resource agency. Source: The list of hunted species was taken primarily from Appendix 2 of the Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement: Issuance of Annual Regulations Permitting the Sport Hunting of Migratory Birds (SEIS 88), U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
==Controversy== {{Criticism section|date=November 2010}} One issue involves a small uninhabited island in the Pacific Ocean known as [[Farallon de Medinilla]] located {{convert|150|mi|km}} north of [[Guam]]. The target range there is the [[United States Pacific Fleet]]'s only U.S.-controlled range available, and conveniently accessible from bases in Guam, for live-fire training. In addition, the air and sea space in the Farallon de Medinilla area provides sufficient room for the many different attack profiles which need to be rehearsed. During the peak of Vietnam War operations, ordnance delivered on the island was estimated at 22 tons per month, but is considerably less now.
The Navy has far more mitigation procedures to prevent environmental damage in the present day than they did in the 1960s. In compliance with the [[National Environmental Policy Act]] of 1969 they prepared an Environmental Impact Statement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/EPA-IMPACT/1995/November/Day-28/pr-1537.html |title=NOI to prepare EIS |date=November 28, 1995 }}</ref> However, the Navy could not guarantee that no bird protected by the MBTA would be killed, despite the precautions. The Fish and Wildlife Service could not grant a permit without such a guarantee, and no permit has been issued. The Navy argued that it had done its best to comply with environmental laws, and should be permitted to operate under the Impact Statement prepared for NEPA. Vice Speaker Joseph P. DeLeon Guerrero, R-Saipan, noted that the U.S. military "is thorough and meticulous in monitoring the impact of the bombing [drills]" on Farallon de Medinilla.
[[Earthjustice]] sued for a temporary restraining order of tests because the navy did not comply with the MBTA, although they did comply with the other environmental laws. As a result, a law was introduced by congress (H.R. 4546) to amend the Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918 to make it lawful for the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] to "take migratory birds during a 'military readiness activity.'" (Readiness activities are defined as all training activities and military operations related to combat and the testing of equipment for combat use.) The record in congress noted that "A recent federal court ruling indicated that the Navy had violated the Migratory Bird Treaty Act by incidentally taking migratory birds without a permit during training exercises near Guam. The House report indicates that the exemption provision is intended to address the lack of permit authorization for incidental takings, so that essential training exercises may proceed. It appears that the language used in the bill would not authorize the issuance of permits, but more broadly would state that the part of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act that articulates unlawful behavior does not apply to a military readiness activity.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/govdocs/crs//data/2002/upl-meta-crs-2518/meta-crs-2518.ocr |title=Order Code RL31456 Report for Congress |accessdate=9 January 2009 }}</ref>
==Proposed amendments== *[[H.R. 3109 (113th Congress)|To amend the Migratory Bird Treaty Act to exempt certain Alaskan Native articles from prohibitions against sale of items containing nonedible migratory bird parts (H.R. 3109; 113th Congress)]] ‚Äì a bill that would allow [[Alaskan Native]]s to make and sell traditional [[handicrafts]] such as [[masks]], [[jewelry]], [[clothing]], and [[hunting]] equipment that are made from parts of migratory birds, particularly [[feather]]s.<ref name=cbo3109>{{cite web|title=CBO ‚Äì H.R. 3109|url=http://www.cbo.gov/publication/45659|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|accessdate=8 September 2014}}</ref><ref name=3109sum>{{cite web|title=H.R. 3109 ‚Äì Summary|url=https://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/3109|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=8 September 2014}}</ref> The bill passed in the [[United States House of Representatives]] in a [[voice vote]] on September 8, 2014.<ref name=3109allactions>{{cite web|title=H.R. 3109 ‚Äì All Actions|url=https://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/3109/all-actions|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=8 September 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Agreed Measures for the Conservation of Antarctic Fauna and Flora]] *[[Convention on Biological Diversity]] *[[Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna]] (CITES) *[[Endangered Species Act]] *[[Bald and Golden Eagle Protection Act]] *[[Environmental agreement]] *[[Ramsar Convention]] *[[sinkbox]] *''[[Missouri v. Holland]]'' *[[Migratory Birds Convention Act]], the Canadian law implementing the treaty
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.fws.gov/birds/management/managed-species/migratory-bird-treaty-act-protected-species.php List of bird species covered under the Migratory Bird Treaty] * [https://www.fws.gov/migratorybirds/RegulationsPolicies/mbta/mbtintro.html U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's guide to U.S. laws protecting migratory birds (including the Migratory Bird Treaty)] {{US Environmental law}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Migratory Bird Treaty Act Of 1918}} [[Category:1918 in law]] [[Category:Bird conservation]] [[Category:United States federal environmental legislation]] [[Category:1918 in the United States]] [[Category:1918 in international relations]] [[Category:1918 in the environment]] [[Category:International environmental law]] [[Category:Environmental law in Canada]] [[Category:Bird hunting]] [[Category:Bird migration]]

revision.text:
[[Postal codes]] in [[Luxembourg]] are entirely numeric and consist of four digits. The first digit indicates the region, however this subdivision of the territory does not correspond exactly to the usual administrative subdivision (districts and cantons).
Postal codes starting with a 1 or a 2 are located in the capital city of Luxembourg.
Postal codes starting with a 3 are located South of the capital city.
Postal codes starting with a 4 are located in the city of [[Esch-sur-Alzette]].
Postal codes starting with a 5 are located in the South-East of the country.
Postal codes starting with a 6 are located in the North-East of the country.
Postal codes starting with a 7 are located North of the capital city.
Postal codes starting with an 8 are located in the West of the country.
Postal codes starting with a 9 are located in the North of the country.
In larger municipalities every street has its own postal code, smaller municipalities often have only one code for the whole town. If there are several postal codes within one municipality, they are ordered alphabetically, except that the first numbers are reserved for important clients (administrations and companies).
==External links== *[https://www.post.lu/en/grandes-entreprises/solutions-postales/rechercher-un-code-postal Search for a postcode in Luxembourg] *[https://github.com/TrustChainEG/postal-codes-json-xml-csv Liechtenstein Postal Codes in XML, JSON and CSV format]
{{Europe in topic|Postal codes in|UK_only=yes}}
[[Category:Postal codes by country|Luxembourg]] [[Category:Postal system of Luxembourg]]
{{Luxembourg-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Menorca |latin = Dioecesis Minoricensis | local = Di√≥cesis de Menorca''(es)''
Bisbat de Menorca''(ca)'' | image = Minorca 0054.JPG | image_size = 230px | image_alt = | caption = [[Minorca Cathedral]] |country = [[Spain]] |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Valencia in Spain|Valencia]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Valencia in Spain|Valencia]] |established = 500 |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = [[Minorca Cathedral|Cathedral Basilica of St Mary in Ciudadela Menorca]] |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 701 |population = 81,288 |population_as_of = 2004 |catholics = 76,000 |catholics_percent= 93.5 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Salvador Gim√©nez Valls]] |metro_archbishop = [[Antonio Ca√±izares Llovera]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= |map = Localitzaci√≥ de Menorca respecte les Illes Balears.svg |map_caption = The Diocese of Menorca in blue. |website = [http://www.bisbatdemenorca.com/ Website of the Diocese] }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Menorca''' ({{lang-la|Minoricen(sis)}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the island of [[Menorca]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Valencia in Spain|Valencia]] in Spain. ==History== It was established as the Diocese of Menorca in the 5th century.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} ==Leadership== *Antonio Vila Campos (18 Dec 1797 ‚Äì 20 Dec 1802) *Pedro Antonio Juano (20 Dec 1802 ‚Äì 4 Jan 1814) *Santiago Creus Mart√≠ (11 Jul 1815 ‚Äì 29 May 1820) *Antonio Ceruelo Sanz (30 May 1824 ‚Äì 15 Jan 1831) *Juan Antonio D√≠ez Merino, O.P. (26 Mar 1831 ‚Äì 16 Apr 1844) *Tom√°s Roda Rodr√≠guez (27 Sep 1852 ‚Äì 20 Dec 1857) *Mateo Jaume Garau (21 Dec 1857 ‚Äì 17 Sep 1875) *Manuel Mercader y Arroyo (17 Sep 1875 ‚Äì 21 Feb 1890) *Juan Comes y Vidal (26 Jun 1890 ‚Äì 25 Jun 1896) *Salvador Castellote y Pinazo (25 Jun 1896 ‚Äì 26 Dec 1901) *Juan Torres Ribas (9 Jun 1902 ‚Äì 20 Jan 1939) *Bartolom√© Pascual Marroig (4 Mar 1939 ‚Äì 18 Mar 1967) *Miguel Moncadas Noguera (11 Dec 1968 ‚Äì 1 Apr 1977) *Antonio Deig Clotet (20 Sep 1977 ‚Äì 7 Mar 1990) *Francesc-Xavier Ciuraneta Aym√≠ (12 Jun 1991 ‚Äì 29 Oct 1999) *Juan Piris Fr√≠gola (1 Mar 2001 ‚Äì 16 Jul 2008) *Salvador Gim√©nez Valls (21 May 2009 ‚Äì ) ==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Spain]] ==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/meno1.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dmeno.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://www3.planalfa.es/obmenorca/ Diocese website] {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain}} {{coord|39|57|N|4|3|E|source:cawiki_region:ES|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Menorca}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain]] [[Category:Dioceses established in the 5th century]] {{Spain-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

{{Infobox scientist | name = Trista Vick-Majors | image = Trista.Vick.Majors.jpg | birth_name = | nationality = United States | fields = Biogeochemisty
[[Microbial ecology]] | workplaces = BSc [[Colorado College]]
PhD [[Montana State University]] | alma_mater = [[Montana State University]] | website = http://tristavickmajors.weebly.com }} '''Trista Vick-Majors''' is an American [[Antarctic]] biogeochemist and [[Microbial ecology|microbial ecologist]], best known for her work showing that microorganisms are present under the [[Antarctic ice sheet]].{{Cite web|url=http://discovermagazine.com/2013/julyaug/15-first-life-found-in-ancient-lake-miles-below-antarctica#.Ue8ILNJwe5J|title=Life Under Antarctica's Ice {{!}} DiscoverMagazine.com|website=Discover Magazine|access-date=2016-06-19}} == Early life and education == Vick-Majors grew up in [[Calhan, Colorado]] and completed her BA in Biology at [[Colorado College]] in 2003. Vick-Majors spent two years studying the microbial ecology of hot springs at the [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas|University of Nevada-Las Vegas]] and graduated with her MSc from [[Montana State University]] in 2010. Vick-Majors earned her PhD in Ecology and Environmental Sciences from Montana State University in 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.montana.edu/gradschool/admissions/profiles/profile_pages/profile_vick_majors.html|title=Catching Up With an Alumna: Trista Vick-Majors|last=|first=|date=|website=Graduate School, Montana State University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2016-06-19}} Vick-Majors‚Äô MSc work focused on the responses of [[heterotroph]]ic microorganisms to the onset of the [[polar night]] in Antarctica,{{Cite journal|last=Vick-Majors|first=Trista J.|last2=Priscu|first2=John C.|last3=Amaral-Zettler|first3=Linda A.|date=2014-04-01|title=Modular community structure suggests metabolic plasticity during the transition to polar night in ice-covered Antarctic lakes|journal=The ISME Journal|volume=8|issue=4|pages=778‚Äì789|doi=10.1038/ismej.2013.190|issn=1751-7370|pmc=3960534|pmid=24152712}}{{Cite journal|last=Vick|first=Trista J.|last2=Priscu|first2=John C.|date=2012-12-18|title=Bacterioplankton productivity in lakes of the Taylor Valley, Antarctica, during the polar night transition|url=http://www.int-res.com/abstracts/ame/v68/n1/p77-90/|journal=Aquatic Microbial Ecology|volume=68|issue=1|pages=77‚Äì90|doi=10.3354/ame01604}} while her PhD focused on microbial ecology and biogeochemistry in Subglacial [[Lake Whillans]] and under the [[McMurdo Ice Shelf]].{{Cite journal|last=Christner|first=Brent C.|last2=Priscu|first2=John C.|last3=Achberger|first3=Amanda M.|last4=Barbante|first4=Carlo|last5=Carter|first5=Sasha P.|last6=Christianson|first6=Knut|last7=Michaud|first7=Alexander B.|last8=Mikucki|first8=Jill A.|last9=Mitchell|first9=Andrew C.|title=A microbial ecosystem beneath the West Antarctic ice sheet|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature13667|journal=Nature|volume=512|issue=7514|pages=310‚Äì313|doi=10.1038/nature13667|pmid=25143114|year=2014|bibcode=2014Natur.512..310.}}{{Cite journal|last=Vick-Majors|first=Trista J.|last2=Achberger|first2=Amanda|last3=Santib√°√±ez|first3=Pamela|last4=Dore|first4=John E.|last5=Hodson|first5=Timothy|last6=Michaud|first6=Alexander B.|last7=Christner|first7=Brent C.|last8=Mikucki|first8=Jill|last9=Skidmore|first9=Mark L.|date=2016-03-01|title=Biogeochemistry and microbial diversity in the marine cavity beneath the McMurdo Ice Shelf, Antarctica|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/lno.10234/abstract|journal=Limnology and Oceanography|language=en|volume=61|issue=2|pages=572‚Äì586|doi=10.1002/lno.10234|issn=1939-5590|bibcode=2016LimOc..61..572V}} == Career and impact == Vick-Majors is a biogeochemist and microbial ecologist with interests in carbon biogeochemistry, polar environments, aquatic ecology, and subglacial ecosystems.{{Cite web|url=http://tristavickmajors.weebly.com|title=Trista J. Vick-Majors|website=Trista J. Vick-Majors|access-date=2016-06-19}} Vick-Majors began working in the Antarctic in 2008 as part of an [[International Polar Year]]-funded project to study ecosystem responses to the Antarctic Polar Night ‚Äì the first expedition of its kind,{{Cite web|url=http://www.montana.edu/priscu/research/ipy/|title=IPY Polar Night 2008 Project - Priscu Research Group {{!}} Montana State University|website=www.montana.edu|access-date=2016-06-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/science/contenthandler.cfm?id=1283|title=The Antarctic Sun: News about Antarctica - Polar Night in the Valleys|website=antarcticsun.usap.gov|access-date=2016-06-19}} and has since been involved in Antarctic expeditions to the McMurdo Dry Valleys, the McMurdo Ice Shelf, Subglacial Lake Whillans in West Antarctica, and to the Ross Ice Shelf.{{Cite web|url=http://www.montana.edu/news/11639/msu-grad-students-part-of-historic-expedition-in-antarctica|title=MSU grad students part of historic expedition in Antarctica|website=Montana State University|language=en-us|access-date=2016-06-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/discovery-fish-live-beneath-antarctica/|title=Discovery: Fish Live beneath Antarctica|last=Fox|first=Douglas|website=Scientific American|access-date=2016-06-19}} Vick-Majors was part of the first field team (the Whillans Ice Stream Subglacial Access Research and Drilling project (WISSARD)) to successfully obtain samples from an Antarctic subglacial lake.{{Cite web|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/02/130205-antarctica-ice-life-moons-science-environment-lakes/|title=Life Found Deep Under Antarctic Ice for First Time? U.S. scientists discover microbes in lake a half-mile under the surface|last=Kaufman|first=Marc|date=February 6, 2013|website=|publisher=National Geographic|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Her work with WISSARD showed that microorganisms are present under the Antarctic ice sheet. Vick-Majors has contributed to the advancement of early career researchers in the polar sciences through her work with the Association of Polar Early Career Scientists{{Cite web|url=https://eos.org/meeting-reports/focus-on-the-future-of-polar-research|title=Focus on the Future of Polar Research - Eos|website=Eos|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-19}} and to public education and outreach efforts,{{Cite web|url=http://gazette.com/manitou-kids-hear-about-going-south-way-south/article/1507536|title=Manitou kids hear about going south - way south|website=Colorado Springs Gazette|access-date=2016-06-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/education/article_06440882-d7a6-11e2-a033-001a4bcf887a.html?mode=jqm|title=Kids practice science at MSU camp|last=Writer|first=TROY CARTER, Staff|website=Bozeman Daily Chronicle|access-date=2016-06-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cssciencecenter.org/calendars/events/160-antarctic-discovery-lectures---innovation-in-antarctic-microbiology-and-volcanoes-in-antarctica|title=Antarctic Discovery Lectures - Innovation in Antarctic Microbiology, and Volcanoes in Antarctica|website=www.cssciencecenter.org|access-date=2016-06-19}} and the popular press.{{Cite web|url=http://www.outtherepodcast.com/episodes/2015/5/10/episode-5-searching-for-life-beneath-the-antarctic-ice-sheet|title=Episode 5: Life In The Antarctic|website=Out There|access-date=2016-06-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.outtherepodcast.com/episodes/2015/8/20/episode-9-life-beneath-the-ice|title=Episode 10: Life Beneath the Ice|website=Out There|access-date=2016-06-19}} == Awards and honours == Vick-Majors was awarded the American Fellowship by the [[American Association of University Women]] in 2014, to support her dissertation work and in recognition of her commitment to helping women and girls through service to her community.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aauw.org/aauw_check/fellowships_directory/#rid3561|title=AAUW Fellows|website=AAUW: Empowering Women Since 1881|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.aauw.org/what-we-do/educational-funding-and-awards/american-fellowships/|title=American Fellowships|website=AAUW: Empowering Women Since 1881|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-19}} Vick-Majors has also been a fellow of the Institute on Ecosystems (2014 and 2015){{Cite web|url=http://montanaioe.org/article/msu-graduate-students-receive-funding-environmental-research|title=MSU graduate students receive funding for environmental research {{!}} Institute on Ecosystems|website=montanaioe.org|access-date=2016-06-19}} and the Montana Space Grant Consortium.{{Cite web|url=http://spacegrant.montana.edu/2009-2010awards.htm|title=<2009-2010awards>|website=spacegrant.montana.edu|access-date=2016-06-19}} == Selected bibliography == *Vick, TJ; Dodsworth, Jeremy A; Costa, KC; Shock, EL; Hedlund, Brian P; (2010) Microbiology and geochemistry of Little Hot Creek, a hot spring environment in the Long Valley Caldera. Geobiology 8(2)140-154{{Cite journal|last=Vick|first=T. J.|last2=Dodsworth|first2=J. A.|last3=Costa|first3=K. C.|last4=Shock|first4=E. L.|last5=Hedlund|first5=B. P.|date=2010-03-01|title=Microbiology and geochemistry of Little Hot Creek, a hot spring environment in the Long Valley Caldera|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1472-4669.2009.00228.x/abstract|journal=Geobiology|language=en|volume=8|issue=2|pages=140‚Äì154|doi=10.1111/j.1472-4669.2009.00228.x|pmid=20002204|issn=1472-4669}} *Christner, Brent C; Priscu, John C; Achberger, Amanda M; Barbante, Carlo; Carter, Sasha P; Christianson, Knut; Michaud, Alexander B; Mikucki, Jill A; Mitchell, Andrew C; Skidmore, Mark L, Vick-Majors, Trista J. (2014) A microbial ecosystem beneath the West Antarctic ice sheet Nature 512,7514:310-313. *Vick-Majors, Trista J; Priscu, John C; Amaral-Zettler, Linda A (2014) Modular community structure suggests metabolic plasticity during the transition to polar night in ice-covered Antarctic lakes,The ISME Journal 8:4,778-789{{Cite journal|last=Vick-Majors|first=Trista J.|last2=Priscu|first2=John C.|last3=Amaral-Zettler|first3=Linda A.|date=2014-04-01|title=Modular community structure suggests metabolic plasticity during the transition to polar night in ice-covered Antarctic lakes|url=http://www.nature.com/ismej/journal/v8/n4/abs/ismej2013190a.html|journal=The ISME Journal|language=en|volume=8|issue=4|pages=778‚Äì789|doi=10.1038/ismej.2013.190|issn=1751-7362|pmc=3960534|pmid=24152712}} == References == {{Reflist|35em}} == External links == * [http://tristavickmajors.weebly.com Trista Vick-Majors's webpage] * [https://scholar.google.com.au/citations?user=KF1V35wAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao Trista Vick-Majors] on [[Google scholar]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vick-Majors, Trista}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American women scientists]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Colorado College alumni]] [[Category:Montana State University alumni]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Biogeochemists]]

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|All typo fixes]] on, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: r‚Äôs ‚Üí r's (8)
revision.text:
[[File:Waldseemuller map 2.jpg|thumb|350px|''Universalis Cosmographia'', the Waldseem√ºller wall map dated 1507, depicts the [[Americas]], [[Africa]], [[Europe]], [[Asia]], and the [[Pacific Ocean]] separating Asia from the Americas, by the Italian [[Amerigo Vespucci]].]] [[File:Waldseemuller map closeup with America.jpg|thumb|350px|Detail of the map showing the name "America".]] [[File:Waldseemuller map closeup with Catigara and Mallaqua.jpg|thumb|350px|Detail of the map showing the names "Catigara" and "Mallaqua".]] The '''Waldseem√ºller map''' or '''''Universalis Cosmographia''''' ("Universal [[Cosmography]]") is a printed wall map of the world by [[Germans|German]] [[cartography|cartographer]] [[Martin Waldseem√ºller]], originally published in April 1507. It is known as the first map to use the name "[[Americas|America]]". The name ''America'' is placed on what is now called [[South America]] on the main map. As explained in ''[[Cosmographiae Introductio]]'', the name was bestowed in honor of the [[Italians|Italian]] [[Amerigo Vespucci]].
The map is drafted on a modification of [[Claudius Ptolemy|Ptolemy's]] second projection, expanded to accommodate the Americas and the high latitudes.<ref name=Snyder>Snyder, John P. (1993). ''Flattening the Earth: 2000 Years of Map Projections'', p. 33. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press.</ref> A single copy of the map survives, presently housed at the [[Library of Congress]] in Washington, D.C.
Waldseem√ºller also created globe [[gore (segment)|gores]], printed maps designed to be cut out and pasted onto spheres to form globes of the Earth. The wall map, and his globe gores of the same date, depict the American continents in two pieces. These depictions differ from the small inset map in the top border of the wall map, which shows the two American continents joined by an [[isthmus]].
==Wall map==
===Description=== The wall map consists of twelve sections printed from woodcuts measuring {{convert|18|x|24.5|in|cm}}. Each section is one of four horizontally and three vertically, when assembled. The map uses a modified Ptolemaic [[map projection]] with curved meridians to depict the entire surface of the Earth. In the upper-mid part of the main map there is inset another, miniature world map representing to some extent an alternative view of the world.
[[Longitude]]s, which were difficult to determine at the time, are given in terms of degrees east from the [[Fortunate Islands]] (considered by [[Claudius Ptolemy]] as the westernmost known land) which Waldseem√ºller locates at the [[Canary Islands]]. The longitudes of eastern Asian places are too great. Latitudes, which were easy to determine, are also quite far off. For example, "Serraleona" ([[Sierra Leone]], true latitude about 9¬∞N) is placed south of the equator, and the [[Cape of Good Hope]] (true latitude 35¬∞S) is placed at 50¬∞S.
The full title of the map is ''Universalis cosmographia secundum Ptholomaei traditionem et Americi Vespucii aliorumque lustrationes'' (The Universal Cosmography according to the Tradition of Ptolemy and the Discoveries of [[Amerigo Vespucci]] and others<ref name="hebert">{{cite journal | first=John R. | last=H√©bert | url=http://loc.gov/loc/lcib/0309/maps.html | title=The Map That Named America | journal=Library of Congress Information Bulletin | publisher=Library of Congress | location=Washington, D.C. | date=September 2003 | accessdate=16 April 2012}}</ref>). One of the "others" was [[Christopher Columbus]]. The title signalled his intention to combine or harmonize in a unified cosmographic depiction the traditional Ptolemaic geography of Europe, Asia and Africa with the new geographical information provided by [[Amerigo Vespucci]] and his fellow discoverers of lands in the western hemisphere. He explained: "In designing the sheets of our world-map we have not followed Ptolemy in every respect, particularly as regards the new lands ... We have therefore followed, on the flat map, Ptolemy, except for the new lands and some other things, but on the solid globe, which accompanies the flat map, the description of Amerigo that is appended hereto."<ref>"nos in depingendis tabulis typi generalis non omnimodo sequutos esse Ptholomaeum, praesertim circa novas terras ... Et ita quidem temporavimus rem ut in plano, circa novas terras & alia quaepiam, Ptholomaeum; in solido vero quod plano additur, descriptionem Americi subsequentem sectatati fuerimus." Martin Waldseem√ºller, ''Cosmographi√¶ Introductio,'' cap.ix, f.19 [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=-pARAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT72&lpg=PT72&dq=%22temporauimus+rem%22&source=bl&ots=glyWJtoJY-&sig=NVmq5NJNFLU54nw52suRl0Hj9xQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QiXjU8bgCsPp8AXk9IJA&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22temporauimus%20rem%22&f=false]; transcribed and translated in Marie Armand Pascal d'Avezac, ''Martin Hylacomylus Waltzem√ºller, ses ouvrages et ses collaborateurs,'' Paris, Challamel, 1867, p.39.[https://archive.org/stream/martinhylacomyl00dgoog#page/n49/mode/1up]</ref>
Several earlier maps are believed to be sources, chiefly those based on the [[Geography (Ptolemy)]] and the Caveri [[planisphere]] and others similar to those of [[Henricus Martellus]] or [[Martin Behaim]]. The [[Caribbean]] and what appears to be [[Florida]] were depicted on two earlier charts, the [[Cantino planisphere|Cantino map]], smuggled from Portugal to Italy in 1502 showing details known in 1500, and the [[Caverio map]], drawn circa 1503‚Äì1504 and showing the [[Gulf of Mexico]].
While some maps after 1500 show, with ambiguity, an eastern coastline for [[Asia]] distinct from the [[Americas]], the Waldseem√ºller map apparently indicates the existence of a new ocean between the trans-Atlantic regions of the Spanish discoveries and the Asia of Ptolemy and Marco Polo as exhibited on the 1492 Behaim globe. The first historical records of Europeans to set eyes on this ocean, the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]], are recorded as [[Vasco N√∫√±ez de Balboa]] in 1513. That is five to six years after Waldseem√ºller made his map. In addition, the map apparently predicts the width of South America at certain latitudes to within 70 miles.<ref name="reuters">{{Cite news|first=David|last=Alexander|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSN0332239320071203?sp=true|title=Map that named America is a puzzle for researchers|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=2007-12-05|accessdate=2007-12-05}}</ref> However, as pointed out by E.G. Ravenstein, this is an illusory effect of the cordiform projection used by Waldseem√ºller, for when the map is laid out on a more familiar [[equirectangular projection]] and compared with others of the period also set out on that same projection there is little difference between them: this is particularly evident when the comparison is made with [[Johannes Sch√∂ner]]'s 1515 globe.<ref name=Ravenstein>E.G. Ravenstein, ''Martin Behaim: His Life and His Globe,'' London, George Philip, 1908, p. 36.</ref>
[[File:Waldseem√ºller quadratic.jpg|thumb|Waldseem√ºller's 1507 map of America re-drawn on an equirectangular projection and on the same uniform scale as that of Sch√∂ner of 1515, so as to be readily comparable.<ref name=Ravenstein/>]] [[File:Sch√∂ner quadratic.jpg|thumb|Sch√∂ner's 1515 map of America re-drawn on an equirectangular projection and on the same uniform scale as that of Waldseem√ºller of 1507, so as to be readily comparable.<ref name=Ravenstein/>]]
Apparently among most map-makers until that time, it was still erroneously believed that the lands discovered by [[Christopher Columbus]], Vespucci, and others formed part of the [[Indies]] of Asia. Thus some believe that it is impossible that Waldseem√ºller could have known about the Pacific, which is depicted on his map. The historian Peter Whitfield has theorized that Waldseem√ºller incorporated the ocean into his map because Vespucci's accounts of the Americas, with their so-called "savage" peoples, could not be reconciled with contemporary knowledge of [[India]], [[China]], and the islands of Indies. Thus, in the view of Whitfield, Waldseem√ºller reasoned that the newly discovered lands could not be part of Asia, but must be separate from it, a leap of intuition that was later proved uncannily precise.<ref name="NYT">{{cite web | first=Richard | last=Bernstein | url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/98/06/21/daily/whitfield-book-review.html | title=The Map Maker's Vision, Skewed Yet Indomitable | journal=New York Times | publisher=The New York Times Company | date=June 24, 1998 | quote=This 1507 map, Mr. Whitfield reminds us, is "one of the most intriguing and enigmatic in the history of cartography". | accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref> An alternative explanation is that of George E. Nunn (see below).
''Mundus Novus'', a book attributed to Vespucci (who had himself explored the extensive eastern coast of South America), was widely published throughout Europe after 1504, including by Waldseem√ºller's group in 1507. It had first introduced to Europeans the idea that this was a new continent and ''not'' Asia. It is theorized that this led to Waldseem√ºller's separating the Americas from Asia, depicting the Pacific Ocean, and the use of the first name of Vespucci on his map.<ref name="hebert"/>
An explanatory text, the ''Cosmographiae Introductio'', widely believed to have been written by Waldseem√ºller's colleague [[Matthias Ringmann]], accompanied the map. It was said in Chapter IX of that text that the earth was now known to be divided into four parts, of which Europe, Asia and Africa, being contiguous with each other, were continents, while the fourth part, America, was "an island, inasmuch as it is found to be surrounded on all sides by the seas".<ref>Hunc in modum terra iam quadripartita cognoscitur: & sunt tres primae partes continentes: quarta est insula: cum omni quamque mari circumdata conspiciatur ... Nunc vero & haec partes sunt latius lustratae & alia quarta pars per Americum Vesputium (ut in sequentibus audietur) inuenta est.</ref>
The inscription on the top left corner of the map proclaims that the discovery of America by Columbus and Vespucci fulfilled a prophecy of the Roman poet, [[Virgil]], made in the [[Aeneid]] (VI. 795‚Äì797), of a land to be found in the southern hemisphere, to the south of the Tropic of Capricorn:
{{quote|Many have thought to be an invention what the famous Poet said, that "a land lies beyond the stars, beyond the paths of the year and the sun, where Atlas the heaven-bearer turns on his shoulder the axis of the world set with blazing stars"; but now, at last, it proves clearly to have been true. It is, in fact, the land discovered by the King of Castile's captain, Columbus, and by Americus Vesputius, men of great and excellent talent, of which the greater part lies under the path of the year and sun, and between the tropics but extending nonetheless to about nineteen degrees beyond Capricorn toward the Antarctic pole beyond the paths of the year and the sun. Wherein, indeed, a greater amount of gold is to be found than of any other metal.}}
The "path" referred to is the ecliptic, which marks the sun's yearly movement along the constellations of the zodiac, so that to go beyond it meant crossing the southernmost extent of the ecliptic, the Tropic of Capricorn. 19¬∞ beyond Capricorn is latitude 42¬∞ South, the southernmost extent of America shown on Waldseem√ºller's map. The map legend shows how Waldseem√ºller strove to reconcile the new geographic information with the knowledge inherited from antiquity.<ref>Archibald Freeman and Emerson David Fite, ''A Book of Old Maps delineating American History from the Earliest Days down to the Close of the Revolutionary War,'' Cambridge (Mass.), Harvard Univ. Press, 1926, p. 26</ref><ref>Valerie I. J. Flint, ''The Imaginative Landscape of Christopher Columbus,'' Princeton, 1992, 84 n. 8).</ref>
The most southerly feature named on the coast of ''America'' on the Waldseem√ºller map is ''Rio decananorum'', the "River of the Cananoreans". This was taken from Vespucci, who in 1501 during his voyage along this coast reached the port which he called ''Cananor'' (now [[Canan√©ia]]). Cananor was the port of [[Kannur]] in southern India, the farthest port reached in India during the 1500‚Äì1501 voyage of the Portuguese [[Pedro √Ålvares Cabral]], the discoverer of Brazil, two of whose ships were encountered returning from India by Vespucci.<ref>Frederick J. Pohl, ''Amerigo Vespucci: Pilot Major,'' New York, Columbia U.P., 1944, p. 225.</ref> This may be an indication Waldseem√ºller thought that the "River of the Cananoreans" could have actually been in the territory of Cananor in India and that ''America'' was, therefore, part of India.
The name for the northern land mass, ''Parias'', is derived from a passage in the ''Four Voyages of Amerigo Vespucci,'' in which, after several stops, the expedition arrives at a region that was "situated in the torrid zone directly under the parallel which describes the Tropic of Cancer. And this province is called by them [the inhabitants] Parias."<ref>"in torrida zona sita est directe sub paralello qui cancri tropicum describit ... Et p[ro]uincia ipsa Parias ab ipsis nu[n]cupata est". ''Qvattvor Americi Vesputii navigationes,'' sigs. ciiir‚Äìciii v.</ref><ref>Christine R. Johnson, "Renaissance German Cosmographers and The Naming of America", ''Past & Present,'' Number 191, May 2006, pp. 30‚Äì31.</ref> ''Parias'' was described by Waldseem√ºller's follower, [[Johannes Sch√∂ner]] as: "The island of Parias, which is not a part or portion of the foregoing [''America''] but a large, special part of the fourth part of the world", indicating uncertainty as to its situation.<ref name=Schoner>Johannes Schoner, ''Luculentissima quaedam terrae totius descriptio,'' Nuremberg, 1515, Tract. II, fol. 60v</ref><ref>Quoted in [[Chet van Duzer]], ''Johann Sch√∂ner's Globes of 1515: Transcription and Study,'' Philadelphia, American Philosophical Society, 2010, pp. 104‚Äì105.</ref>
<small>''PARIAS''</small> and <small>''AMERICA''</small>, corresponding to North and South America, are separated by a strait in the region of the present Panama on the main map but on the miniature map inset into the upper-mid part of the main map the isthmus joining the two is unbroken, apparently demonstrating Waldseem√ºller's willingness to represent alternative solutions to a question yet unanswered.
The map shows the cities of ''[[Cattigara|Catigara]]'' (near longitude 180¬∞ and latitude 10¬∞S) and ''Mallaqua'' ([[Malacca]], near longitude 170¬∞ and latitude 20¬∞S) on the western coast of the great peninsula that projects from the southeastern part of Asia, or <small>''INDIA MERIDIONALIS''</small> (Southern India) as Waldseem√ºller called it. This peninsula forms the eastern side of the <small>''[[Sinus Magnus|SINUS MAGNUS]]</small>'' ("Great Gulf"), the [[Gulf of Thailand]].<ref>J.W. McCrindle, ''Ancient India as described by Ptolemy,'' London, Trubner, 1885, revised edition by Ramachandra Jain, New Delhi, Today & Tomorrow‚Äôs Printers & Publishers, 1974, p. 204: "By the Great Gulf is meant the Gulf of Siam, together with the sea that stretches beyond it toward China".</ref><ref>Albert Herrmann, ‚ÄúDer Magnus Sinus und Cattigara nach Ptolemaeus‚Äù, ''Comptes Rendus du 15me Congr√®s International de G√©ographie, Amsterdam, 1938,'' Leiden, Brill, 1938, tome II, sect. IV, G√©ographie Historique et Histoire de la G√©ographie, pp. 123‚Äì128.</ref> Amerigo Vespucci, writing of his 1499 voyage, said he had hoped to sail westward from Spain across the Western Ocean (the Atlantic) around the Cape of Cattigara mentioned by Ptolemy into the Sinus Magnus.<ref>Amerigo Vespucci to Lorenzo de'Medici, Seville, 18 July 1500; quoted in Ilaria Luzzana Caraci, ''Amerigo Vespucci,'' Roma, Istituto poligrafico e Zecca dello Stato, Libreria dello Stato, 1996, Vol. 1, p. 133.</ref> Ptolemy understood Cattigara, or [[Kattigara]], to be the most eastern port reached by shipping trading from the Graeco-Roman world to the lands of the Far East. Vespucci failed to find the Cape of Cattigara on his 1499 voyage: he sailed along the coast of Venezuela but not far enough to resolve the question of whether there was a sea passage beyond leading to Ptolemy's Sinus Magnus. The object of his voyage of 1503‚Äì1504 was to reach the fabulous spice emporium of "Melaccha in India" (that is, Malacca, or [[Melaka]], on the Malay Peninsula).<ref>Clements R. Markham, ''The Letters of Amerigo Vespucci: and Other Documents Illustrative of His Career,'' London, Hakluyt Society, 1894, p. 53; ''Lettera di Amerigo Vespucci: delle Isole nuovamente trovate in quattro suoi Viaggi [1504],'' Translated by George Tyler Northrup, Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1916, p. 41.</ref> He had learned of Malacca from one Guaspare (or Gaspard), a pilot with [[Pedro √Ålvares Cabral]]'s fleet on its voyage to India in 1500‚Äì1501, whom Vespucci had encountered in the Atlantic on his return from India in May 1501.<ref name=Armesto2007>Felipe Fern√°ndez-Armesto, ''Amerigo: The Man who gave his Name to America,'' New York, Random House, 2007, pp. 86, 168.</ref> Christopher Columbus, in his fourth and last voyage of 1502‚Äì1503, planned to follow the coast of [[Champa]] southward around the Cape of Cattigara and sail through the strait separating Cattigara from the New World, into the [[Sinus Magnus]] to Malacca. This was the route he understood [[Marco Polo]] to have gone from China to India in 1292 (although Malacca had not yet been founded in Polo's time).<ref name=Nunn3M>http://www.henry-davis.com/MAPS/Ren/Ren1/304.1.html; cited in George E. Nunn, "The Three Maplets attributed to Bartholomew Columbus", ''Imago Mundi,'' vol. 9, 1952, 12‚Äì22.</ref>{{rp|15}}<ref>Helen Wallis, "What Columbus Knew", ''History Today,'' vol. 42, May 1992, pp. 17‚Äì23</ref><ref>Edmundo O'Gorman, ''The Invention of America: An Inquiry into the Historical Nature of the New World and the Meaning of its History,'' Bloomington, Indiana University Press, 1961, pp. 106‚Äì122.</ref> Columbus anticipated that he would meet up with the expedition sent at the same time from Portugal to Malacca around the Cape of Good Hope under [[Vasco da Gama]], and carried letters of credence from the Spanish monarchs to present to da Gama.<ref>The letter, dated 14 March 1502, is published in Martin Fernandez de Navarrete, ''Coleccion de los Viages y Descubrimientos,'' 2nd. edn., Madrid, Imprenta Nacional, 1858, p. 430</ref><ref>The covering letter to Columbus is published in A. Millares Carlo (ed.), ''Historia de las Indias por Fray Bart√≥lome de las Casas,'' M√©xico, Fondo de Cultura Economica, 1951, Lib. 2, cap.iv, pp. 219‚Äì220.</ref> The map therefore shows the two cities that were the initial destinations of Amerigo Vespucci and Christopher Columbus in their voyages that led to the unexpected discovery of a New World.<ref name=Armesto2007/><ref>Felipe Fern√°ndez-Armesto, ''Columbus,'' Oxford, Oxford University Press, 1991, pp. 162, 165.</ref>
Just to the south of ''Mallaqua'' ([[Malacca]]) is the inscription: ''hic occisus est S. thomas'' (Here St. Thomas was killed), referring to the legend that Saint [[Thomas the Apostle]] went to India in 52 AD and was killed there in 72 AD. Waldseem√ºller had confused Malacca (Melaka) with [[Mylapore]] in India.<ref>Ivar Hallberg, ''[https://archive.org/details/lextrmeorientd00halluoft L'Extr√™me Orient dans la litt√©rature et la cartographie de l'Occident des XIIIe, XIVe, et XVe Si√®cles],'' G√∂teborg, Zachryssons, 1906, p. 355</ref><ref name=Schoner/> The contemporary understanding of the nature of Columbus' discoveries is demonstrated in the letter written to him by the Aragonese cosmographer and Royal counsellor, Jaume Ferrer, dated 5 August 1495, saying: Divine and infallible Providence sent the great Thomas from the Occident into the Orient in order to declare in India our Holy and Catholic Law; and you, Sir, it has sent to this opposite part of the Orient by way of the Ponient [West] so that by the Divine Will you might arrive in the Orient, and in the farthest parts of India Superior in order that the descendants might hear that which their ancestors neglected concerning the teaching of Thomas ... and very soon you will be by the Divine Grace in the Sinus Magnus, near which the glorious Thomas left his sacred body".<ref>Martin Fernandez de Navarrete, ''Coleccion de los Viages y Descubrimientos,'' Madrid, Imprenta Nacional, 1825‚Äì1837, Vol. II, 104.</ref><ref>John Boyd Thacher, ''Christopher Columbus: His Life, His Work, His Remains,'' New York, 1903, Vol. II, 365‚Äì366.</ref>
===History=== At the time this wall map was drawn, Waldseem√ºller was working as part of the group of scholars of the Vosgean Gymnasium at [[Saint-Di√©-des-Vosges]] in [[Lorraine (province)|Lorraine]], which in that time belonged to the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. The maps were accompanied by the book ''Cosmographiae Introductio'' produced by the Vosgean Gymnasium.
[[File:LoC Treasures Gallery Waldseem√ºller map display 2007.jpg|thumb|A facsimile of the Waldseem√ºller map is prominently displayed in the Treasures Gallery of the Library of Congress in [[Washington, DC]].]] Of the one thousand copies of the wall map Waldseem√ºller stated were printed, only one complete copy is known.<ref>{{Cite news|first=Toby |last=Lester |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The map that changed the world |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/8328878.stm |quote=Waldseemuller himself would later record that 1,000 copies of the map had been printed, a very substantial number for the day. But the rapid pace of geographical discovery meant that copies of the map were soon discarded in favour of newer, more up-to-date pictures of the world, and by 1570 it had all but vanished from memory. |work=[[BBC]] |date=October 28, 2009 |accessdate=2009-10-28 }}</ref> It was originally owned by [[Johannes Sch√∂ner]] (1477‚Äì1547), a [[Nuremberg]] astronomer, geographer, and cartographer. Its existence was unknown for a long time until its rediscovery in 1901 in the library of Prince Johannes zu [[Waldburg-Wolfegg]] in [[Schloss Wolfegg]] in [[W√ºrttemberg]], [[Germany]] by the [[Jesuit]] historian and cartographer [[Joseph Fischer (cartographer)|Joseph Fischer]]. It remained there until 2001 when the [[United States]] [[Library of Congress]] purchased it from Waldburg-Wolfegg-Waldsee for ten million dollars.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2001/01-093.html|title=Library Acquires Only Known Copy of 1507 World Map Compiled by Martin Waldseem√ºller|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|date=2001-07-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2003/03-110.html|title=Library Completes Purchase of Waldseem√ºller Map|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|date=2003-06-18}}</ref>
Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] of the Federal Republic of Germany symbolically turned over the Waldseem√ºller map on April 30, 2007, within the context of a formal ceremony at the [[Library of Congress]], in Washington, DC. In her remarks, the chancellor stressed that the US contributions to the development of Germany in the postwar period tipped the scales in the decision to turn over the Waldseem√ºller map to the [[Library of Congress]] as a sign of transatlantic affinity and as an indication of the numerous German roots to the United States. Today another [[facsimile]] of the map is exhibited for the public by the [[House of Waldburg]] in their museum on [[Waldburg Castle]] in [[Upper Swabia]].
Since 2007, to the celebration of the 500 year jubilee of the first edition, the original map has been permanently displayed in the Library of Congress, within a specially-designed microclimate case. An [[argon]] atmosphere fills the case to give an anoxic environment. Prior to display, the entire map was the subject of a scientific analysis project using hyperspectral imaging with an advanced LED camera and illumination system<ref>https://www.loc.gov/preserv/rt/projects/hyperspec_imaging.html</ref> to address preservation storage and display issues.<ref>https://www.loc.gov/preservation/outreach/tops/france_easton/</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2007/07-143.html|title=Construction Under Way for Encasement of the 1507 Waldseem√ºller Map|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|date=2007-06-29}}</ref>
In 2005 the Waldseem√ºller map was nominated by Librarian of Congress [[James H. Billington]] for inscription on [[UNESCO]]'s [[Memory of the World Register]] and was inscribed on the register that same year.<ref name=mow>{{Cite web |title= Universalis cosmographia secundum Ptholomaei traditionem et Americi Vespucii aliorumque Lustrationes |url= http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/memory-of-the-world/register/full-list-of-registered-heritage/registered-heritage-page-9/universalis-cosmographia-secundum-ptholomaei-traditionem-et-americi-vespucii-aliorumque-lustrationes/ |publisher= UNESCO Memory of the World Programme |accessdate= 2017-12-07 }}</ref>
===Nunn's analysis=== The geographers of Italy and Germany, like Martin Waldseem√ºller and his colleagues, were exponents of a [[theoretical geography]], or cosmography. This means they appealed to theory where their knowledge of the American and Asiatic geography was lacking. That practice differed from the official Portuguese and Spanish cartographers, who omitted from their maps all unexplored coastlines.<ref name=NunnCaM>George E. Nunn, ''The Columbus and Magellan Concepts of South American Geography,'' Glenside, Beans Library, 1932.</ref>{{rp|5-7,12-13,49-51}}
The second century Alexandrian geographer [[Claudius Ptolemy]] had believed that the known world extended over 180 degrees of longitude from the prime meridian of the [[Fortunate Isles]] (possibly the [[Canary Islands]]) to the city of ''[[Cattigara]]'' in southeastern Asia.<ref>"cum prisci Cosmographi & praesertim Ptolemaeus longitudines locorum a fortunatis insulis in Orientem usque in Cattgaram, Centum, & octoginta gradibus metirentur" (the ancient cosmographers, above all Ptolemy, calculated 180 degrees of longitude from the Fortunate Isles/Canaries to Cattigara in the East) : Maximilianus Transsylvanus, ''De Moluccis Insulis,'' Cologne, 1523, cap. 4. See [[Oc Eo]]</ref> (In fact, the difference in longitude between the Canaries, at 16¬∞W, and Cattigara, at 105¬∞E, is just 121¬∞.) He had also thought that the Indian Ocean was completely surrounded by land. Marco Polo demonstrated that an ocean lay east of Asia and was connected with the Indian Ocean. Hence, on the globe made by Martin Behaim in 1492, which combined the geography of Ptolemy with that of Marco Polo, the Indian Ocean was shown as merging with the Western Ocean to the east. Ptolemy's lands to the east of the Indian Ocean, however, were retained in the form of a great promontory projecting far south from the southeastern corner of Asia‚Äîthe peninsula of Upper India (India Superior) upon which the city of Cattigara was situated.
Another result of Marco Polo's travels was also shown on Behaim's globe‚Äîthe addition of 60 degrees to the longitude of Asia. Columbus had not actually seen Behaim's globe in 1492 (which apparently owed much to the ideas of [[Paolo dal Pozzo Toscanelli]]); but the globe, except for one important point, reflects the geographical theory on which he apparently based his plan for his first voyage. The exception is that Columbus shortened the length of the degree, thus reducing the distance from the Canaries to ''Zipangu'' (Japan), to about 62 degrees or only 775 leagues. Consequently, it seemed to Columbus a relatively simple matter to reach Asia by sailing west.
In the early 16th century, two theories prevailed with regard to ''America'' (the present South America). According to one theory, that continent was identified with the southeastern promontory of Asia that figures on Behaim's globe, India Superior or the Cape of Cattigara. The other view was that ''America'' (South America) was a huge island wholly unconnected with Asia.<ref name=NunnCaM/>{{rp|12-13,49-51}}
It should be noted that Balboa called the Pacific the ''Mar del Sur'' and referred to it as "la otra mar", the other sea, by contrast with the Atlantic, evidently with Behaim's concept of only two oceans in mind.<ref>Angel de Altolaguirre y Duvale, ''Vasco N√∫√±ez de Balboa,'' Madrid, 1914, pp. 16, 19‚Äì21; cited in George E. Nunn, "Magellan‚Äôs Route in the Pacific", ''The Geographical Review,'' vol. 24, no. 4, October 1934, p. 627.</ref> The ''Mar del Sur'', the South Sea, was the part of the Indian Ocean to the south of Asia: the Indian Ocean was the ''Oceanus Orientalis,'' the Eastern Ocean, as opposed to the Atlantic or Western Ocean, the ''Oceanus Occidentalis'' in Behaim's two ocean world.<ref name=NunnCaM/>{{rp|57}}
According to George E. Nunn, the key to Waldseem√ºller's apparent new ocean is found on the three sketch maps made by Bartolom√© Colon (that is, Bartholomew Columbus, Christopher's brother) and Alessandro Zorzi in 1504 to demonstrate the geographical concepts of Christopher Columbus. One of the Columbus/Zorzi sketch maps bears an inscription saying that: "According to [[Marinus of Tyre]] and Columbus, from Cape St. Vincent to Cattigara is 225 degrees, which is 15 hours; according to Ptolemy as far as Cattigara 180 degrees, which is 12 hours".<ref>"Alberico", vol. IV, c. 169, Florence, Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale, Banco Rari 234</ref><ref>Sebastian Crino, "Schizzi cartografici inediti dei primi anni della scoperta dell' America", ''Rivista marittima,'' vol. LXIV, no. 9, Supplemento, Novembre 1930, p. 48, fig. 18.</ref><ref name=Nunn3M/> This shows that Christopher Columbus overestimated the distance eastward between Portugal and Cattigara as being 225 degrees instead of Ptolemy's estimate of 180 degrees, permitting him to believe the distance westward was only 135 degrees and therefore that the land he found was the East Indies. As noted by Nunn, in accordance with this calculation, the Colon/Zorzi maps employ the longitude estimate of Claudius Ptolemy from Cape St. Vincent eastward to Cattigara, but the longitude calculation of Marinus and Columbus is employed for the space between Cape St. Vincent westward to Cattigara.
Nunn pointed out that Martin Waldseem√ºller devised a scheme that showed both the Columbus and the Ptolemy-Behaim concept on the same map. On the right hand side of the Waldseem√ºller 1507 map is shown the Ptolemy-Behaim concept with the Ptolemy longitudes: this shows the huge peninsula of India Superior extending to the south of the Tropic of Capricorn. On the left side of the Waldseem√ºller map the discoveries of Columbus, Vespucci and others are represented as a long strip of land extending from about latitude 50 degree North to latitude 40 degrees South. The western coasts of these trans-Atlantic lands discovered under the Spanish crown are simply described by Waldseem√ºller as ''Terra Incognita'' (Unknown Land) or ''Terra Ulterior Incognita'' (Unknown Land Beyond), with a conjectural sea to the west, making these lands apparently a distinct continent. ''America's'' (that is, South America's) status as a separate island or a part of Asia, specifically, the peninsula of India Superior upon which Cattigara was situated, is left unresolved. As the question of which of the two alternative concepts was correct had not been resolved at the time, both were represented on the same map. Both extremities of the map represent the eastern extremity of Asia, according to the two alternative theories. As Nunn said, "This was a very plausible way of presenting a problem at the time insoluble."<ref name=NunnLGG>George E. Nunn, "The Lost Globe Gores of Johann Sch√∂ner, 1523‚Äì1524", ''The Geographical Review,'' vol. 17, no. 3, July 1927, pp. 476-480 https://www.jstor.org/stable/pdfplus/208330.pdf?acceptTC=true</ref>{{rp|479‚Äì480}}<ref name=NunnWM>George E. Nunn, ''The World Map of Francesco Roselli,'' Philadelphia, Beans Library, 1928.</ref>{{rp|8-9,25}}
As noted by Nunn, the distance between the meridians on the map is different going eastward and westward from the prime meridian which passes through the [[Fortunate Isles]] (Canary Islands). This has the effect of representing the eastern coast of Asia twice: once in accordance with Ptolemy's longitudes to show it as Martin Behaim had done on his 1492 globe; and again in accordance with Columbus' calculation of longitudes to show his and the other Spanish navigators' discoveries across the Western Ocean, which Columbus and his followers considered to be part of India Superior.<ref name=NunnLGG/>{{rp|479}}<ref>George E. Nunn, ''Origin of the Strait of Anian Concept,'' Philadelphia, Beans Library, 1929.</ref>{{rp|2-7}}
On his 1516 world map, the ''Carta Marina,'' Waldseem√ºller identified the land he had called ''Parias'' on his 1507 map as ''Terra de Cuba'' and said it was part of Asia (''Asie partis''), that is, he explicitly idendified the land discovered by Columbus as the eastern part of Asia.<ref name=NunnWM/>{{rp|8}}
==Gores== [[File:Waldseem√ºller-Globus.jpg|thumb|left|Waldseem√ºller gores of 1507]] Besides ''Universalis Cosmographia'', Waldseem√ºller published a set of gores for constructing globes. The gores, also containing the inscription ''America'', are believed to have been printed in the same year as the wall map, since Waldseem√ºller mentions them in the introduction to his ''Cosmographi√¶ Introductio''.<ref name=Shirley>Shirley, Rodney W. (1993). ''The Mapping of the World'', p. 29. London: New Holland (Publishers) Ltd.</ref> On the globe gores, the sea to the west of the notional American west coast is named the ''Occeanus Occidentalis,'' that is, the Western or Atlantic Ocean, and where it merges with the ''Oceanus Orientalis'' (the Eastern, or Indian Ocean) is hidden by the latitude staff. This appears to indicate uncertainty as to ''America's'' location, whether it was an island continent in the Atlantic (Western Ocean) or in fact the great peninsula of India Superior shown on earlier maps, such as the 1489 map of the world by Martellus or the 1492 globe of [[Behaim]].<ref name=NunnCaM/>{{rp|12-13,49-51}} [[File:Waldseem√ºller Globensegmente Cim107-2.jpg|thumb|right|The fifth copy, slightly different from the others]] Only few copies of the globe gores are extant. The first to be rediscovered was found in 1871 and is now in the James Ford Bell Library of the [[University of Minnesota]].<ref>{{Citation | title = Maps & Mapmakers - Martin Waldseemuller | year = 2005 | url = https://www.lib.umn.edu/apps/bell/WaldsWebsite/AtTheBell_globe.htm | accessdate = 2012-07-03}}</ref> Another copy was found inside a Ptolemy atlas and had been in the Bavarian State Library in Munich since 1990. The Library recognized in February 2018, after reviewing its authenticity, that this map is not an original copy - it was printed in the 20th century. <ref>{{Citation | title = Bayerische Staatsbibliothek: Waldseem√ºllerkarte in M√ºnchen: "Unzweifelhaft eine F√§lschung" - Bavarian State Library: Waldseem√ºller map in Munich: "Undoubtedly a fake" | year = 2018 | url = https://www.br.de/nachrichten/waldseemueller-karte-unzweifelhaft-eine-faelschung-bayerische-staatsbibliothek-100.html | accessdate = 2018-02-17}}</ref> A third copy was discovered in 1992 bound into an edition of Aristotle in the Stadtb√ºcherei [[Offenburg]], a public library in Germany. A fourth copy came to light in 2003 when its European owner read a newspaper article about the Waldseem√ºller map. It was sold at auction to Charles Frodsham & Co. for $1,002,267, a world record price for a single sheet map.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/europe/06/08/america.map/index.html |title=First map of America makes $1m |publisher=[[CNN]].com |date=2003-06-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060529102930/http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/europe/06/08/america.map/index.html |archivedate=May 29, 2006 }}</ref> In July 2012, a statement was released from [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich]] that a fifth copy of the gore had been found in the LMU Library's collection which is somewhat different from the other copies, perhaps because of a later date of printing.<ref>{{cite web | title = Details, Date, and Significance of the Fifth Set of Waldseem√ºller‚Äôs Globe Gores Recently Discovered in the Munich University Library | publisher = Ludwig-Maximilians-Universit√§t M√ºnchen | url =https://razoncartografica.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/van-duzer-waldseemuller-globe-gores-munich-english.pdf | accessdate = 2016-02-02}}</ref> LMU Library has made an electronic version of their copy of the map available online.<ref>{{Citation | last = Waldseem√ºller | first = Martin | title = Globensegmente | date = after 1507 | url = http://epub.ub.uni-muenchen.de/13138/ | accessdate = 2012-07-03}}</ref>
